revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=October 2015}} [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Sang Hyang dans TMnr 60052123.jpg|thumb|right|The sacred [[Balinese dance]] Sanghyang Dedari involved girls being possessed by [[hyang]]s.]]
'''Sanghyang''' is a sacred [[Balinese dance]], based on the idea that a force enters the body of an [[trance|entranced]] [[performer]]. The force, identified as ''[[hyang]]'', is important spiritual entities in ancient [[Culture of Indonesia|Indonesian]] mythology.
The sanghyang dances are considered sacred ritual dances that should be performed only in [[Balinese Hinduism|Hindu Balinese]] religious events, never merely to entertain tourists.<ref>[http://www.babadbali.com/seni/drama/dt-sanghyang-dedari.htm Babad Bali]</ref>{{request quotation|date=October 2015}}
== Variants<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.babadbali.com/seni/drama/dt-sanghyang-dedari.htm |author=Team Survey ASTI |title=TARI SANGHYANG|accessdate=August 24, 2018}}</ref>== ===Sanghyang Bojog=== The dancer is a man dressed like a monkey (''bojog'') and accompanied by a chorus of chanting Sanghyang. Before it began, the dancer went through the phases of summoning ape spirits. After conceding, the dancer will jump onto the tree and mimic the behavior of an ape. This dance only found at [[Bugbug|Bugbug, Karangasem]].
===Sanghyang Celeng=== This is Sanghyang dance variant only found at [[Karangasem Regency|Duda, Karangasem]], danced by a man using clothing from palm fiber, he went around and mimicked the movements of a pig.
===Sanghyang Dedari=== Sanghyang dedari is a [[dance]] performed by pre-pubescent girls, similar in some ways to the [[Legong]] dance. Often the girls are carried on the shoulders of men, and trance is associated with this [[ritual]].
===Sanghyang Deling=== Survived by a pair of not yet puberty little girls who entered the spirit of Goddess Sri (Goddess of Fertility). Each dancer holds a tree linked to a thread where two suspended dolls are made from a lontar leaf called ''deling''
===Sanghyang Grodog=== This danced by 23 person, who each person having different character each other.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.beritabali.com/read/2016/08/22/201608220003/Sang-Hyang-Grodog-Tari-Sakral-Yang-Melegenda-di-Nusa-Lembongan.html|title=Sang Hyang Grodog, Tari Sakral Yang Melegenda di Nusa Lembongan |accessdate=August 24, 2018}}</ref>
===Sanghyang Jaran=== Sanghyang jaran is a dance performed by boys who ride coconut [[Hobby horse#Indonesia|hobbyhorses]] ([[Kuda Lumping]]) in and around a fire. Trance is also associated with this ritual.
===Sanghyang Sampat=== Drawn by a girl who has conceded a spirit with an intermediate broomstick (''sampat'') that is moved freely to the left and right. There are also similar dances which are a piece of bamboo, called Sanghyang Bungbung dance.
==See also== *[[Balinese dance]]
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wBLYvVpF-TA&feature=related Youtube video of Sanghyang] * [http://www.baliyes.com/bali-culture/Sanghyang-Jaran-Dance Sanghyang-Jaran-Dance] * [http://www.indo.com/featured_article/sanghyang.html sanghyang] {{Dance in Bali}}
[[Category:Dances of Bali]] [[Category:Sacred dance]]
{{Dance-stub}}

{{Infobox album | name = Symphony of Decay | type = EP | artist = [[Third Eye Blind]] | cover = | alt = | released = Unreleased | recorded = 2000-2004 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]] | length = | label = [[Elektra Records]] | producer = [[Stephan Jenkins]] | prev_title = [[Blue (Third Eye Blind album)|Blue]] | prev_year = 1999 | year = Unreleased | next_title = [[Out of the Vein]] | next_year = 2003 }} '''''Symphony of Decay''''' is a [[Extended play|EP]] by American [[alternative rock]] band [[Third Eye Blind]]. The EP started off under the working title of '''''Black''''' as a companion EP to their [[RIAA|platinum selling]] 1999 album ''[[Blue (Third Eye Blind album)|Blue]]''. Its creation was a result of a compromise over the release method of the track "Slow Motion"; the band had wanted it on ''Blue'', while their [[record label]], [[Elektra Records]], opposed its inclusion on such a high-profile full-length album release due to its controversial lyrics. The EP would go through years of delays for a multitude of reasons, including extensive touring, prioritizing the completion of their third studio album ''[[Out of the Vein]]'', and complications arising from parting ways with Elektra in 2004. The EP itself was never collectively released, though many of the tracks were eventually released elsewhere.
==Background== After the band's six times [[RIAA|platinum]]-selling self-titled ''[[Third Eye Blind (album)|Third Eye Blind]]'' album, the band reconvened to record a follow up album, ''[[Blue (Third Eye Blind album)|Blue]]'', in early 1999. During the ''Blue'' sessions, the band recorded a track called "Slow Motion" which had been used in their 1994 demo tape.<ref name="ABC1">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/story?id=111594&page=1|title=Third Eye Blind Album Details|date=6 January 2006|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> However, [[Elektra Records|Elektra]], the band's [[record label]], did not approve of the song's lyrical content about a student who shoots a teacher's son, with the [[Columbine High School massacre]] having just occurred the same year.<ref name="MTV1">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/520169/third-eye-blind-set-sights-on-ep-for-censored-song/|title=Third Eye Blind Set Sights On EP For Censored Song|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> The band argued with the label for over four months over the content and its inclusion on the album.<ref name="MTV1"/> The final agreement between the two parties was that the song could only be on the album as an instrumental, but in return, Elektra would finance a separate [[extended play|EP]] where the song could be placed with its full controversial lyrics.<ref name="ABC1"/>
While the arrangement was made just prior to the release of ''Blue'', work on the EP, tentatively titled ''Black'' as a companion release to ''Blue'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/WPcap/1999-12/31/003r-123199-idx.html|title=An Unobstructed View of Third Eye Blind|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> wasn't set to begin until late 2000, upon completion of the "Red Summer Sun Tour" in support of ''Blue''.<ref name="MTV2">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/871374/third-eye-blind-to-record-concept-ep/|title=Third Eye Blind To Record Concept EP|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> However, in 2000, frontman [[Stephan Jenkins]] fell into a state of [[depression (mood)|depression]], which led him to recluse himself into a productive period of writing, resulting in over 40 new songs.<ref name="MTV3">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1446738/third-eye-blind-head-to-studio-may-get-help-from-fred-durst/|title=Third Eye Blind Head To Studio, May Get Help From Fred Durst|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> This activity led the band to focus on releasing another full-length album first - what would become ''[[Out of the Vein]]'' - with intentions of releasing an EP afterwards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/71119/third-eye-blind-inspired-after-hiatus|title=Third Eye Blind Inspired After Hiatus|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> After the ''Out of the Vein'' sessions, the band started referring to the EP title as ''Symphony of Decay''.<ref name="mel1"/> A month after the release of ''Out of the Vein'', in June 2003, Jenkins stated to [[VH1]] that the band planned on releasing the EP as soon as September of the same year.<ref name="mel3">{{cite web|url=http://www.melodic.net/?page=news&id=732|title=Melodic Net - New 3eb Ep In Sept.|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> However, the EP was later delayed into 2004,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.melodic.net/?page=news&id=2250 |title=Melodic Net - Third Eye Blind News,stephan Producing Vanessa And New Ep On The Way |publisher=Melodic.net |date=2004-03-14 |accessdate=2018-08-19}}</ref> and then again into 2005.<ref name="mel1">{{cite web|url=http://www.melodic.net/?page=news&id=3204|title=Melodic Net - Third Eye Blind Ep "Symphony Of Decay" Out Early 2005|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> Drummer [[Brad Hargreaves]], in late 2004, indicated that the EP had become tied up with difficulties with their record label, with Elektra dropping the band after the low sales of ''Out of the Vein''.<ref name="mel2"/>
==Concept== The terms of the compromise resulting in the EP's conception gave the band considerable freedom in their work; it was financed by Elektra,<ref name="ABC1"/> but ultimately treated as an independent release, allowing the band creative control.<ref name="MTV2"/> The EP was envisioned as a seven<ref name="MTV1"/> to eight<ref name="mel1"/> song release where the songs would flow together and collectively have a run-time of about 50 minutes, resulting in lengthier run-times for some songs.<ref name="MTV2"/> Jenkins described the band's intent as wanting to "perform like a little symphony" to ultimately "make something really beautiful", while the band's manager at the time, Eric Godtland, stated that they would be "stringing together songs" to create "more of a cohesive vision that flows."<ref name="MTV2"/>
==Aftermath== While the EP was never officially released, a number of the tracks eventually found release in various forms. The full-lyrics version of "Slow Motion" finally found a vehicle for its official release in the band's 2006 [[greatest hits]] album ''[[A Collection (Third Eye Blind album)|A Collection]]''.<ref name="melGH">{{cite web|url=http://www.melodic.net/?page=news&id=6100|title=Melodic Net - Third Eye Blind Releases Collection Of Hits And Rarities|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> The vocals and piano recording of "My Time in Exile" was also included on ''A Collection''.<ref name="melGH"/> The track "Carnival Barker", in its entirety, was released as a free download by the band in 2006,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.melodic.net/?page=news&id=6157|title=Melodic Net - New Instrumental Track With 3eb Available For Download|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> while a brief clip of it was included as the closing track of the band's fourth album, ''[[Ursa Major (album)|Ursa Major]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/ursa-major-mw0000822715|title=Ursa Major - Third Eye Blind - Songs, Reviews, Credits - AllMusic|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> The track "There's No Hurry to Eternity" was eventually released on the charity benefit [[compilation album]] ''Live from Nowhere Near You Vol. II'' in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/live-from-nowhere-near-you-vol-2-pacific-northwest-mw0002183949|title=Live From Nowhere Near You, Vol. 2: Pacific Northwest - Various Artists - Songs, Reviews, Credits - AllMusic|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> The track had previously been titled as "[[Elliott Smith]]".<ref name="mel2">{{cite web|url=http://www.melodic.net/?page=news&id=2911|title=Melodic Net - Third Eye Blind Update On The "Lost" Ep And A Sideproject|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> "Knife in the Water", "Animal", and the full band version of "My Time in Exile" all unofficially [[internet leak|leaked onto the internet]] between 2005 and 2006. No versions of "Star Wars" or "Swimming" have ever been released or leaked, although the latter was temporarily listed as a potential track for ''Ursa Major''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.melodic.net/?page=news&id=7022|title=Melodic Net - Third Eye Blind Currently Working On Album #4|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref>
In 2008, the band would finally release an EP, the unrelated, politically-themed three track EP ''[[Red Star (EP)|Red Star]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2008/11/album-review-red-star-ep/|title=Album Review: Third Eye Blind – Red Star [EP]|date=27 November 2008|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref>
==Track list== '''''Symphony of Decay''''' {{Track listing | all_lyrics = | all_music = | title1 = Animal | length1 = 2:52 | title2 = My Time in Exile (full band version) | length2 = 3:17 | title3 = Star Wars | length3 = - | title4 = Carnival Barker | length4 = 7:11 | title5 = Slow Motion | length5 = 4:34 | title6 = Swimming | length6 = - | title7 = Elliott Smith/There's No Hurry to Eternity | length7 = 6:16 | title8 = Knife in the Water | length8 = 4:27 }}
==Personnel== * [[Stephan Jenkins]] - [[lead vocals]],<ref name="MTV2"/> [[drum kit|drums]] on "There's No Hurry to Eternity"<ref name="NHTEcredits"/> * Tony Fredianelli - [[lead guitar]]<ref name="MTV2"/> * Arion Salazar - [[bass guitar|bass]], guitar on "There's No Hurry to Eternity"<ref name="NHTEcredits">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/live-from-nowhere-near-you-vol-2-pacific-northwest-mw0002183949/credits|title=Live From Nowhere Near You, Vol. 2: Pacific Northwest - Various Artists - Credits - AllMusic|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref> * [[Brad Hargreaves]] - drums, [[percussion]]<ref name="mel2"/>

revision.text:
{{infobox artwork | image=Giovanni bellini, episodio della vita di publio cornelio scipione, post 1506, 2.JPG | title=The Continence of Scipio | artist=[[Giovanni Bellini]] | year= 1507-1508 | medium=oil on canvas | height_metric=74.8 | width_metric=356.2 | city=[[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] | museum=[[National Gallery of Art]] }} {{More citations needed|date=February 2018}} '''''The Continence of Scipio''''' or '''''An Episode from the Life of Publius Cornelius Scipio''''' is a long oil on canvas painting by [[Giovanni Bellini]], dating to 1507-1508 and now in the [[National Gallery of Art]] in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nga.gov/collection/art-object-page.41589.html|title=Catalogue entry}}</ref>
==History== It was probably commissioned in 1505 from [[Andrea Mantegna]] by cardinal [[Marco Cornaro (cardinal)|Marco Cornaro]] for the 'studiolo' or study of his brother [[Francesco Cornaro (cardinal)|Francesco]]'s palace in [[San Polo]]. This would make it a pendant to ''[[The Introduction of the Cult of Cybele at Rome]]'', with the pair possibly intended to form part of a series of four works. However, Mantegna did not begin any of the four except ''Introduction'', the only one that Mantegna he completed before his death in 1506. He and Bellini had trained together as young men and the latter was also the former's brother in law. Bellini was himself an old man by 1506 but still took over this part of the commission and produced it in one of Mantegna's signature styles, [[grisaille]] (monochrome). [[Roberto Longhi]] has suggested that ''Sofonisba'' and ''Tuccia'' from Mantegna's ''[[Exemplary Women of Antiquity]]'' series were produced to go with ''Introduction'' and ''Continence'' - they are the same height as them but are on panel not canvas and no documents survive to support the theory.
[[File:Giovanni Bellini Continence of Scipio.jpg|thumb|left|200px|First half]] [[File:Continence of Scipio (Bellini).jpg|thumb|right|200px|Second half]] Francesco Cornaro was a Venetian patrician and his family was supposed to be descended from the [[Cornelia (gens)|Cornelia]] [[gens]] of ancient Rome, hence the choice of two subjects from that gens' participation in the [[Second Punic War]]. ''Continence'' is derived from a story in [[Livy]] and [[Valerius Maximus]] about the aftermath of the capture of [[Carthage]] in 209 BC by [[Scipio Africanus|Publius Cornelius Scipio]]. A virgin was personally delivered to him as a hostage, but she pleaded to be returned to her parents and [[Celtiberians|Celtiberian]] fiancé. He agreed on the single condition that her fiancé would work for peace between Rome and Carthage. Just left of centre Scipio sits on a throne and refuses the gold brought to him by the woman's parents as her ransom. She stands at the foot of his throne with her fiancé, who is shown with a sword and helmet. Between Scipio and the virgin is a plaque reading <small>TVRPIVS / IMPER / VENERE / .Q. A. / MIS AI</small>. The more peripheral figures were painted by Bellini's studio and overall his and their figures show more animation than Mantegna's more rigid classicism, showing that Bellini had taken on board innovations by [[Giorgione]] but refused to be influenced by [[Dürer]].
The work reappeared on the art market in 1873 when it was sold by Sir John Charles Robinson (1824-1913) to [[Francis Cook, 1st Viscount of Monserrate|Sir Francis Cook]] (1817-1901) of Doughty House, [[Richmond-upon-Thames]]. Cook's son [[Sir Frederick Cook, 2nd Baronet|Frederick Lucas]], grandson [[Herbert Cook|Herbert Frederick]] and great-grandson [[Sir Francis Cook, 4th Baronet|Francis Ferdinand Maurice]] all inherited the painting in turn. Sir Francis Ferdinand Maurice Cook sold it in February 1948 to Gualtiero Volterra, who was buying it on behalf of count [[Alessandro Contini-Bonacossi]] of [[Florence]]. The count briefly brought it back to Italy before selling it to the [[Samuel H. Kress]] Foundation in March 1949. The Foundation finally gave it to its current owner in 1952.<ref>{{it icon}} Mariolina Olivari, ''Giovanni Bellini'', in AA.VV., ''Pittori del Rinascimento'', Scala, Firenze 2007. {{ISBN|888117099X}}</ref>
==References== <references/>

{{Infobox film | name = The Eagle with Two Heads | image = Eagletwoheads.jpg | image_size = | caption = | director = [[Jean Cocteau]] | producer = [[Georges Dancigers]]
[[Alexandre Mnouchkine]] | writer = Jean Cocteau | narrator = | starring = [[Edwige Feuillère]]
[[Jean Marais]]
[[Jean Debucourt]]
[[Silvia Monfort]]
[[Jacques Varennes]] | music = [[Georges Auric]] | cinematography = [[Christian Matras (cinematographer)|Christian Matras]] | editing = [[Claude Ibéria]]
[[Raymond Leboursier]] | distributor = | released = '''France''':
22 September 1948
'''United States''':
18 December 1948 | runtime = 93 min. | country = France | language = French | budget = | gross = 2,408,366 admissions (France){{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficestory.com/box-office-jean-marais-c22695355|title=Box Office Figures for Jean Marais films|website=Box Office Story}} | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Eagle with Two Heads''''' (French title '''''L'Aigle à deux têtes''''') is a French film directed by [[Jean Cocteau]] released in [[1948 in film|1948]]. It was adapted from his own play ''[[L'Aigle à deux têtes]]'' which was first staged in 1946, and it retained the principal actors from the first Paris production. ==Synopsis== On the 10th anniversary of the assassination of the king, his reclusive widow, the Queen, arrives to spend the night at the castle of Krantz. Stanislas, a young [[anarchist]] poet who seeks to assassinate her, enters her room, wounded; he looks exactly like the dead king, and the Queen shelters him instead of handing him over to the police. She sees him as the welcome embodiment of her own death, calling him [[Azrael]] (the angel of death). An ambiguous love develops between them, uniting them in a bid to outwit the machinations of the court politicians, represented by the Comte de Foëhn, the chief of police, and Édith de Berg, the Queen's companion. In order to remain true to their ideals and to each other, the Queen and Stanislas have to play their parts in a bizarre private tragedy, which the world will never understand. ==Cast== *[[Edwige Feuillère]] as the Queen *[[Jean Marais]] as Stanislas *[[Silvia Monfort]] as Édith de Berg *[[Jean Debucourt]] as Félix de Willenstein *[[Jacques Varennes]] as Comte de Foëhn *[[Ahmed Abdallah (actor)|Ahmed Abdallah]] as Tony *[[Yvonne de Bray]] as La présidente ==Production== [[L'Aigle à deux têtes|Cocteau's play]] was produced in Paris in 1946 and 1947, and his decision to make a prompt adaptation for the cinema allowed him to retain the principal actors who had enjoyed personal successes with their roles, especially Edwige Feuillère and Jean Marais. Cocteau declared his intention of following the three-act structure of the play closely, citing his admiration of the methods of [[Ernst Lubitsch]],Jean Cocteau, in ''Combat'', 21 August 1947, quoted in [[Claude-Jean Philippe]], ''Jean Cocteau''. (Paris: Seghers, 1989) p.160: "À l'exemple de Lubitsch, que j'admire beaucoup, le film suivra la pièce de très près. Je l'ai construit autour des trois scènes principales". but he opened out some of the scenes into a wider variety of locations. Filming began in October 1947 at the Château de [[Vizille]],René Gilson, ''Jean Cocteau cinéaste''. (Paris: Éditions des Quatre-Vents, 1988) p.26. and further shots were filmed at the Studio d'Épinay on the outskirts of Paris. [[Christian Bérard]] supervised the art direction, and the sumptuous sets and costumes (executed by [[Georges Wakhévitch]] and [[Marcel Escoffier]] respectively) evoked a royal palace in an imaginary kingdom of 19th century middle-Europe. [[Georges Auric]] expanded the music which he had written for the stage production into a full score for the film. ==Reception== The film was released in Paris in September 1948. Its reception among French critics was mixed. It was appreciated for the sumptuous quality of its spectacle and for the elevated performances of its actors.E.g. Louis Chauvet, ''Le Figaro'', 26 August 1948, quoted in Claude-Jean Philippe, ''Jean Cocteau''. (Paris: Seghers, 1989) p.162: "Les personnages parlent une langue toujours belle, et mêmes leurs attitudes sont belles". Others however felt that its artificiality belonged to another age and another medium, and that Cocteau had not sufficiently emancipated his film from its theatrical origins.André Bazin, ''Parisien'', 29 September 1948, quoted in Claude-Jean Philippe, ''Jean Cocteau''. (Paris: Seghers, 1989) p.160: "''L'Aigle à deux têtes'' laisse indifférent comme un motif décoratif habilement inspiré du style d'une autre époque".Jean Néry, ''L'Écran français'', quoted in Claude-Jean Philippe, ''Jean Cocteau''. (Paris: Seghers, 1989) p.162: "Il n'a pas su (ou pas voulu) s'émanciper des disciplines théâtrales". When the film was shown in New York in 1948 and in London in 1949, the reviewers of both ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''[[The Times]]'' shared a similar perplexity about the film's meaning and purpose.Bosley Crowther, "L'Aigle à deux têtes", in ''New York Times'', 30 December 1948: "It sometimes helps if a reviewer has a faint idea of what a film he is reviewing is supposed to be about... Unfortunately, Mr Cocteau neglected to make it clear... Plenty of money and taste have plainly been spent on a handsome physical production. Hapsburg {{sic}} splendor is in the sets and the costumes which Miss Feuillere fills out are lovely and flattering. But they all add up to nothing."''The Times'' (London), 10 November 1949, p.7, col.C: "The passion of Cocteau for history and for legend, his conception of illusion and reality, his preoccupations with death and doom, his romantic mysticism, so heavy and overcharged that it is difficult to remember that he is a French and not a Teutonic director - all these are indeed present in this new film, but fitfully, as it were, as inadequate exponents of the mood and the motive of the initial impulse. The play may have made things clearer...". The film has in general not enjoyed the same attention as the others which Cocteau directed in the 1940s. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0039135|L'Aigle à deux têtes}} * {{Amg movie|90191|L'Aigle à deux têtes}} *{{bfidb title|129149|L'Aigle à deux têtes}} *[http://filmsdefrance.com/FDF_L_aigle_a_deux_tetes_rev.html ''L'Aigle à deux têtes''] at filmsdefrance.com {{Jean Cocteau}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Eagle With Two Heads, The}} [[Category:1948 films]] [[Category:1940s romantic drama films]] [[Category:French romantic drama films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:Films directed by Jean Cocteau]] [[Category:Screenplays by Jean Cocteau]] [[Category:Films scored by Georges Auric]] [[Category:Adaptations of works by Jean Cocteau]] [[Category:French black-and-white films]] [[Category:Films set in a fictional European country]] [[Category:Films set in the 1890s]] [[Category:Films about anarchism]] [[Category:Films about assassinations]] [[Category:Films about royalty]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Elisabeth, Empress of Austria]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of criminals]]

{{Infobox ballet company | name = Theater of the silence | logo = | local_name = Théâtre du Silence | previous_names = | founded = 1972 | founders = | venue = [[La Rochelle]],
[[France]] {{Flagicon|France}} | website = | chief_executive = | director = Jacques Garnier,
[[Brigitte Lefevre]] | administrator = | ballet_master_in_chief = | associated_schools = | formation = }} The « Théâtre du Silence », theater of the silence in French, was a dance company created by Jacques Garnier and [[Brigitte Lefèvre]].{{cite web|url=http://www.franceinter.fr/emission-jour-de-fred-brigitte-lefevre-reine-des-etoiles|title=Brigitte Lefèvre, reine des Étoiles / France Inter|publisher=franceinter.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ina.fr/video/CPB96003340|title=Brigitte Lefevre la danse passionnement - Vidéo Ina.fr|author=Institut National de l’Audiovisuel – Ina.fr|publisher=ina.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}} == History == Founded by two [[Paris Opera Ballet]] dancers, the « Théâtre du Silence “ was one of the most famous dance companies in [[France]]. First show by this company took place in [[Théâtre de la Ville]], [[Paris]] in 1972 From 1974 to 1985, the "théâtre du silence" had been in residence in [[La Rochelle]]. The company created many contemporary dance ballets, most choreographed by Jacques garnier or Brigitte Lefévre. Others choreographers, like [[Maurice Béjart]], [[Merce Cunningham]], David Gordon, Robert Kovitch ou Lar Lubovitch worked for the “Théâtre du Silence” The "Théâtre du Silence" played an important role in the spreading of dance in France. Some shows took place in schools or retirement homes. == Repertory == === Jacques Garnier === * Suite de danses,{{cite web|url=http://data.bnf.fr/39497015/suite_de_danses_spectacle_1974/|title=Suite de danses - Spectacle - 1974|publisher=data.bnf.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}} on a [[Béla Bartók]] music, costums by Bruno Crespel ; * Pas de deux, [[Anton Webern]] music, costums by Reynaldo Cerqueira, danced by Brigitte Lefèvre and Jacques Garnier ; * La Nuit,{{cite web|url=http://data.bnf.fr/39496880/la_nuit_spectacle_1971/|title=La nuit - Performance - 1971|publisher=data.bnf.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}} musics by [[Jean-Pierre Drouet]], Diego Masson and [[Michel Portal]], danced by Nicole Chouret, Katia Grey, Brigitte Lefevre, Catherine Morel, Annette Mulard, Françoise Vaussenat, Martine Vuillermoz, Richard Duquesnoy, Jean Guizerix, Patrick Marty, Jacques Namont, Didier Schirpaz, Georges Teplitsky, Jean-Marc Torres; * Leda, on a [[Paul Éluard]] text danced by Brigitte Lefèvre, [[Daniel Gélin]] (narrator); * Flashback, creation in [[Avignon]], in August 1974, [[Igor Stravinsky]]’s music, danced by Martine Clary, Mireille Conotte, Élisabeth Nicolas, Michel Bouche, Jacques Garnier, Olivier Marmin, Dragan Mocic, Catherine Morelle, Serge Bonnafoux ; * Construction,{{cite web|url=http://data.bnf.fr/39497014/construction_spectacle_1974/|title=Construction - Spectacle - 1974|publisher=data.bnf.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}} creation in [[Lausanne]], musics by Émile de Ceuninck, danced by Martine Clary, Mireille Conotte, Catherine Morelle, Élisabeth Nicolas, Michel Bouche, Serge Bonnafoux, Olivier Marmin, Dragan Mocic ; * L'Ange,{{cite web|url=http://data.bnf.fr/39497018/l_ange_spectacle_1974/|title=L'ange - Spectacle - 1974|publisher=data.bnf.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}} Jean-Pierre Drouet’s music, claim by Saint Maur, with [[Gérard Frémy]] (musician), Jean-Pierre Drouet (musician), Michaël Denard (angel), Brigitte Lefèvre (She), Jean Guizerix (man) ; * Aunis,{{cite web|url=http://dansercanalhistorique.com/2014/10/11/aunis-de-jacques-garnier/|title=« Aunis  de Jacques Garnier « – Dansercanalhistorique|publisher=dansercanalhistorique.com|accessdate=2015-04-06}} danced in 1980 by Jacques Garnier, André Lafonta and Lari Léong. === Brigitte Lefèvre === * Mikrokosmos,{{cite web|url=http://catalogue.bnf.fr/servlet/biblio?idNoeud=1&ID=41421514&SN1=0&SN2=0&host=catalogue|title=BnF catalogue général - Notice bibliographique|publisher=catalogue.bnf.fr|accessdate=2015-04-06}} [[Béla Bartók]] music, danced by Brigitte Lefèvre, Michaël Denard, Jacques Garnier ; * Un certain temps, [[Terry Riley]]’s music, danced by Martine Clary, Mireille Conotte, Catherine Morelle, Élisabeth Nicolas, Michel Bouche, Jacques Garnier, Olivier Marmin, Dragan Mocic ; * Oiseau triste, [[Maurice Ravel]]’s music, choreographed by Jean Guizerix ; * L'Oiseau de feu, by Michaël Denard (1980) ; * SummerSpace, [[Merce Cunningham]]. == Dancers == * Martine Clary{{cite web|url=http://tempsreel.nouvelobs.com/culture/20140610.OBS9984/disparition-de-la-danseuse-martine-clary.html|title=Disparition de la danseuse Martine Clary- 10 juin 2014 - L'Obs|publisher=tempsreel.nouvelobs.com|accessdate=2015-04-06}} * André Lafonta * Lari Léong * Jean Guizerix * Michaël Denard * Serge Bonnafoux * Olivier Marmin * Dragan Mocic * Catherine Morelle * Mireille Conotte * Nicole Chouret * Annette Mulard * Françoise Vaussenat * Martine Vuillermoz * Richard Duquesnoy * Patrick Marty * Jacques Namont * Didier Schirpaz * Georges Teplitsky * Jean-Marc Torres * Katia Grey * Nicole Chouret * Josyane Consoli * Cooky Chiapalone * Élisabeth Nicolas * Michel Bouche * Stéphanie White{{cite web|url=http://www.cannesdance.com/esdc-stephanie-white-22.html|title=Stéphanie WHITE - Ecole Supérieure de Danse de Cannes Rosella Hightower|publisher=cannesdance.com|accessdate=2015-04-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923200230/http://www.cannesdance.com/esdc-stephanie-white-22.html|archivedate=2015-09-23|df=}} * Nicole-Claire Perreau ==References== {{reflist}} * == External links == * [http://www.numeridanse.tv/en/video/335_aunis Numéridanse] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160303232805/https://www.classicaltv.com/the-informer/jacques-garnier-aunis Classical TV] * [http://www.ina.fr/video/I04161133 INA] * [http://fresques.ina.fr/en-scenes/fiche-media/Scenes06002/brigitte-lefevre.html Fresques INA] {{Ballet companies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Theatre du Silence}} [[Category:History of ballet]] [[Category:Contemporary dance]] [[Category:Modern dance]]

{{about | the play by [[Harley Granville Barker]] | similar terms with different meanings | Waste (disambiguation)}} {{italic title}} {{one source|date=August 2011}} '''''Waste''''' is a play by the English author [[Harley Granville Barker]]. It exists in two wholly different versions, from 1906 and 1927. The first version was refused a licence by the [[Lord Chamberlain]] and had to be performed privately by the [[Stage Society]] in 1907; the second was finally staged in public at the [[Westminster Theatre]] in 1936.
==Plot== The plot centres around ambitious independent politician Henry Trebell, his plans for a bill to [[disestablishment|disestablish]] the [[Church of England]] and his fall from grace and suicide after his affair with married woman Amy O'Connell, who dies after a botched [[abortion]]. The title may refer to the waste of his potential talents due to the scandal, the loss of the disestablishment bill and the termination of Amy's pregnancy.
==Dramatis personae (1927 version)== *Gilbert Wedgecroft, Trebell's doctor *Walter Kent, Trebell's secretary *Amy O'Connell, Trebell's lover *Russell Blackborough, Tory MP and financier *Justin O'Connell, Amy's estranged Irish husband *Lord Charles Cantilupe, Tory MP *Henry Trebell, Independent and later Tory MP *Lady Mortimer, Lady Julia's mother *Bertha, the Trebells' maid *Frances Trebell, Henry's sister *Cyril Horsham, Tory Prime Minister *Lucy Davenport, Kent's fiancee *Butler at the Farrant residence *Vivian Saumarez, Horsham's secretary *George Farrant, Tory MP *Lady Julia Farrant, George's wife
==Production history== Recent productions include John Barton's in 1985 for the Royal Shakespeare Company at the Barbican, with Daniel Massey as Trebell and Judi Dench as Amy, one in 1997 at the [[Old Vic]] by the [[Peter Hall (director)|Peter Hall]] Company (with [[Michael Pennington]] as Trebell, [[Anna Carteret]] as Frances and [[Peter Blythe]] as Charles Cantilupe) and a well-received one at the [[Almeida Theatre]] (directed by [[Samuel West]] and starring [[Will Keen]] as Trebell, [[Nancy Carroll (British actress)|Nancy Carroll]] as Amy and [[Phoebe Nicholls]] as Frances<ref>[http://www.almeida.co.uk/production_details/production_details.aspx?code=72 Almeida homepage for the production]</ref>). Recent North American productions include one in 1995 at the [[Shaw Festival production history#1995|Shaw Festival]] (directed by [[Neil Munro (actor)|Neil Munro]]) and one in 2000 directed by [[Bartlett Sher]]. In November 2015, the National Theatre revived the play, directed by [[Roger Michell]] and starring [[Charles Edwards (English actor)|Charles Edwards]] as Trebell and [[Olivia Williams]] as Amy, using the 1927 version of the text.<ref>[http://www.nationaltheatre.org.uk/shows/waste National Theatre homepage for the production]</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Waste (Play)}} [[Category:English plays]] [[Category:1906 plays]] [[Category:Political fiction]] [[Category:1927 plays]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2017}} [[File:Oer-Weimarer Musenhof.jpg|thumb|300px|''Weimar's Courtyard of the Muses'' (1860) by Theobald Freiherr von Oer. Schiller reads in the gardens of [[Schloss Tiefurt|Tiefurt]] Castle, [[Weimar]]. Amongst the audience, seated at the far left, are Wieland and Herder, while Goethe stands before the pillar, at right.]]
'''Weimar Classicism''' ({{lang-de|Weimarer Klassik}}) was a German [[literary movement|literary]] and [[cultural movement]], whose practitioners established a new [[humanism]], from the synthesis of ideas from [[Romanticism]], [[Classicism]], and the [[Age of Enlightenment]].
The ''Weimarer Klassik'' movement lasted thirty-three years, from 1772 until 1805, and involved intellectuals such as [[Johann Wolfgang Goethe]], [[Johann Gottfried Herder]], [[Friedrich Schiller]], and [[Christoph Martin Wieland]]; and then was concentrated upon Goethe and Schiller during the period 1788–1805.
== Development ==
=== Background === The [[Age of Enlightenment|German Enlightenment]], called "[[Neoclassicism|neo-classical]]", burgeoned in the synthesis of [[Empiricism]] and [[Rationalism]] as developed by [[Christian Thomasius]] (1655–1728) and [[Christian Wolff (philosopher)|Christian Wolff]] (1679–1754). This philosophy, circulated widely in many magazines and journals, profoundly directed the subsequent expansion of [[German language|German]]-speaking and [[European culture|European]] [[culture]].
The inability of this common-sense outlook convincingly to bridge "feeling" and "thought", "body" and "mind", led to [[Immanuel Kant]]'s epochal "critical" philosophy.{{Clarify|date=February 2011}} Another, though not as abstract, approach to this problem was a governing concern with the problems of aesthetics. In his ''Aesthetica'' of 1750 (vol. II; 1758) [[Alexander Baumgarten]] (1714–62) defined "aesthetics", which he coined earlier in 1735, with its current intention as the "science" of the "lower faculties" (i.e., feeling, sensation, imagination, memory, et al.), which earlier figures of the Enlightenment had neglected<!-- needs ref -->. (The term, however, gave way to misunderstandings due to Baumgarten's use of the [[Latin]] in accordance with the German renditions, and consequently this has often led many to falsely undervalue his accomplishment.<ref>Cf. Nivelle, ''Les Théories esthétiques en Allemagne de Baumgarten à Kant''. Bibliothèque de la Faculté de Philosophie et Lettres de l'Université de Liège (Paris, 1955), pp. 21 ff.</ref>) It was no inquiry into taste—into positive or negative appeals—nor sensations as such but rather a way of knowledge. Baumgarten's emphasis on the need for such "sensuous" knowledge was a major abetment to the "pre-Romanticism" known as ''[[Sturm und Drang]]'' (1765), of which [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe|Goethe]] and [[Friedrich Schiller|Schiller]] were notable participants for a time.
=== Cultural and historical context === Following Goethe's competition with and separation from Wieland and Herder, the movement Weimar Classicism is often described to have occurred only between Goethe's first stay in Rome (1786) and the death of Schiller (1805), his close friend and collaborator, underrating especially Wieland's influence on German intellectual and poetic life. Therefore, the Weimar Classicism could also be started with the arrival of Wieland (1772) and extended beyond Schiller's death until the death of Wieland (1813) or even of Goethe himself (1832).
In Italy, Goethe aimed to rediscover himself as a writer and to become an artist, through formal training in Rome, Europe's 'school of art'. While he failed as an artist, Italy appeared to have made him a better writer.
Schiller's evolution as a writer was following a similar path to Goethe's. He had begun as a writer of wild, violent, emotion-driven plays. In the late 1780s he turned to a more classical style. In 1794, Schiller and Goethe became friends and allies in a project to establish new standards for literature and the arts in Germany.
By contrast, the contemporaneous and efflorescing literary movement of [[German Romanticism]] was in opposition to Weimar and German Classicism, especially to Schiller. It is in this way both may be best understood, even to the degree in which Goethe continuously and stringently criticized it through much of his essays, such as "On Dilettantism",<ref>Borchmeyer, op. cit., p. 58.</ref> on art and literature.<!-- Elaborate this particular criticism --> After Schiller's death, the continuity of these objections partly elucidates the nature of Goethe's ideas in art and how they intermingled with his scientific thinking as well,<ref>Vaget, ''Dilettantismus und Meisterschaft. Zum Problem des Dilettantismus bei Goethe: Praxis, Theorie, Zeitkritik'' (Munich: Winkler, 1971).</ref> inasmuch as it gives coherence to Goethe's work. Weimar Classicism may be seen as an attempt to reconcile—in "binary synthesis"—the vivid feeling emphasized by the ''[[Sturm und Drang]]'' movement with the clear thought emphasized by the Enlightenment, thus implying Weimar Classicism is intrinsically un-[[Platonism|Platonic]]. On this Goethe remarked:
{{Quotation|"The idea of the distinction between classical and romantic poetry [''Dichtung''<ref>The [[German language|German]] word has its [[English language|English]] equivalents in "poetry" and "fiction".</ref>], which is now spread over the whole world, and occasions so many quarrels and divisions, came originally from Schiller and myself. I laid down the maxim of objective treatment of poetry, and would allow no other; but Schiller, who worked quite in the subjective way, deemed his own fashion the right one, and to defend himself against me, wrote the treatise upon 'Naïve and Sentimental Poetry.' He proved to me that I myself, against my will, was romantic, and that my 'Iphigenia,' through the predominance of sentiment, was by no means so classical and so much in the antique spirit as some people supposed.
"The Schlegels took up this idea, and carried it further, so that it has now been diffused over the whole world; and every one talks about classicism and romanticism—of which nobody thought fifty years ago."<ref name=Eckermann>Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=eTfyNmEqgb8C&printsec=frontcover&dq=Conversations+with+Eckermann,&source=bl&ots=Ge1R0auvNd&sig=tYMp3X69HCB2HwmxHOGnjNBgnTE&hl=en&ei=jExPTYXtNYbGlQe1xsU7&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDYQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=He%20proved%20to%20me%20that%20I%20myself%2C%20against%20my%20will%2C%20was%20romantic&f=false Conversations With Eckermann (1823-1832)]''.M. Walter Dunne (1901).</ref>}}
The Weimar movement was notable for its inclusion of female writers. ''Die Horen'' included works by several women, including a serially published novel, ''Agnes von Lilien'', by Schiller's sister-in-law [[Caroline von Wolzogen]]. Other women published by Schiller included [[Sophie Mereau]], [[Friederike Brun]], [[Amalie von Imhoff]], [[Elisa von der Recke]], and [[Louise Brachmann]].<ref>Holmgren, Janet Besserer, ''The Women Writers in Schiller's ''Horen'': Patrons, Petticoats, and the Promotion of Weimar Classicism'' (Newark, Delaware: University of Delaware Press, 2007).</ref>
Between 1786 and Schiller's death in 1805, he and Goethe worked to recruit a network of writers, philosophers, scholars and artists to their cause. This alliance later became known as 'Weimar Classicism', and it came to form a part of the foundation of 19th-century Germany's understanding of itself as a culture and the political [[unification of Germany]].
== Aesthetic and philosophical principles == These are essentials used by Goethe and Schiller:<!-- examples of their engagement within texts, such as "Primal Words. Orphic", may be necessary; the desultory conditions of goethe's scientific ideas with his aesthetic ones are truly grown together -->
# ''Gehalt'': the inexpressible "felt-thought", or "import", which is alive in the artist and the percipient that he or she finds means to express within the aesthetic form, hence ''Gehalt'' is implicit with form. A work's ''Gehalt'' is not reducible to its ''Inhalt''. # ''Gestalt'': the aesthetic form, in which the import of the work is stratified, that emerges from the regulation of forms (these being rhetorical, grammatical, intellectual, and so on) abstracted from the world or created by the artist, with sense relationships prevailing within the employed medium. # ''Stoff'': Schiller and Goethe reserve this (almost solely) for the forms taken from the world or that are created. In a work of art, ''Stoff'' (designated as "''Inhalt''", or "content", when observed in this context) is to be "indifferent" ("''gleichgültig''"), that is, it should not arouse undue interest, deflecting attention from the aesthetic form. Indeed, ''Stoff'' (i.e., also the medium through which the artist creates) needs to be in such a complete state of unicity with the ''Gestalt'' of the art-symbol that it cannot be abstracted except at the cost of destroying the aesthetic relations established by the artist.{{Citation needed|reason=How do we know these are "key" terms?|date=March 2016}}
== Primary authors ==
=== Goethe and Schiller ===
Although the vociferously unrestricted, even "organic", works that were produced, such as ''Wilhelm Meister'', ''Faust'', and ''West-östlicher Divan'', where playful and turbulent ironies abound,<ref>Bahr, ''Die Ironie im Späwerk Goethes: "Diese sehr ernsten Scherze": Studien zum West-östlichen Divan, zu den Wanderjahren und zu Faust II'' (Berlin: Erich Schmidt Verlag, 1872).</ref> may perceivably lend Weimar Classicism the double, ironic title "Weimar Romanticism",<ref>Borchmeyer, op. cit., p. 358.</ref> it must nevertheless be understood that Goethe consistently demanded this distance via irony to be imbued within a work for precipitate aesthetic affect.<ref>Goethe's letter to Friedrich Zelter, 25.xii.1829. Cf. "''Spanische Romanzen, übersetzt von Beauregard Pandin''" (1823).</ref>
Schiller was very prolific during this period, writing his plays ''Wallenstein'' (1799), ''Mary Stuart'' (1800), ''The Maid of Orleans'' (1801), ''The Bride of Messina'' (1803) and ''William Tell'' (1804).

=== Christoph Martin Wieland === * ''[[Alceste (Schweitzer)|Alceste]]'', (stage play, 1773, first on stage: Weimar, May 25, 1773) * ''[[Die Geschichte der Abderiten]]'', (novel on ancient [[Abdera, Thrace|Abdera]], Leipzig 1774-1780) * ''Hann und Gulpenheh'', (rhymed novel, Weimar 1778) * ''[[Schach Lolo]]'', (rhymed novel, Weimar 1778) * ''[[Oberon (Wieland)|Oberon]]'', (rhymed novel, Weimar 1780) * ''[[Dschinnistan]]'', (tom. I-III, Winterthur 1786-1789) * ''[[Geheime Geschichte des Philosophen Peregrinus Proteus]]'', (novel, Weimar 1788/89; Leipzig 1791) * ''[[Agathodämon]]'', (novel, Leipzig 1796-1797) * ''[[Aristipp und einige seiner Zeitgenossen]]'', (novel on [[Aristippus]], tom. Ein Schauspiel für Liebende'' (stag play, 1776) * ''Iphigenie auf Tauris'' ("[[Iphigenia in Tauris (Goethe)|Iphigenia in Tauris]]", stage play, printed 1787) * ''[[Torquato Tasso (Goethe)|Torquato Tasso]]'' (stage play, 1780-, printed 1790) * ''[[Römische Elegien]]'' (written 1788–90) * ''[[Venezianische Epigramme]]'' (1790) * ''Faust. Eine Tragödie'' ("[[Goethe's Faust|Faust]]" I, 1797-, first print 1808) * ''[[Novelle (Goethe)|Novelle]]'' (1797- ) * ''Hermann und Dorothea'' ("[[Hermann and Dorothea]]", hexametric epos, 1798) * ''[[Die natürliche Tochter]]'' (stage play, 1804) * ''Die Wahlverwandtschaften'' ("[[Elective Affinities]]", novel, 1809)
=== Friedrich (von) Schiller === * ''[[Don Karlos]]'', (stage play, 1787) * ''[[Über den Grund des Vergnügens an tragischen Gegenständen]]'', (essay, 1792) * ''[[Augustenburger Briefe]]'', (essays, 1793) * ''[[Über Anmut und Würde]]'', (essay, 1793) * ''[[Kallias-Briefe]]'', (essays, 1793) * ''[[Über die ästhetische Erziehung des Menschen]]'', ("On the Aesthetic Education of Man", essays, 1795) * ''[[Über naive und sentimentalische Dichtung]]'', (essay, 1795) * ''[[Der Taucher]]'', (poem, 1797) * ''[[Die Kraniche des Ibykus]]'', (poem, 1797) * ''[[Ritter Toggenburg]]'', (poem, 1797) * ''[[Der Ring des Polykrates (poem)|Der Ring des Polykrates]]'', (poem, 7987) * ''Der Geisterseher'', ("[[The Ghost-seer]]", (1789) * ''[[Die Bürgschaft]]'', (poem, 1798) * ''[[Wallenstein (play)|Wallenstein]]'' (trilogy of stage plays, 1799) * ''[[Das Lied von der Glocke]]'' (poem, 1799) * ''Maria Stuart'' ("[[Mary Stuart (play)|Mary Stuart]]", stage play, 1800) * ''[[Die Jungfrau von Orleans]]'' ("The Maid of Orleans", stage play, 1801) * ''[[Die Braut von Messina]]'' ("The Bride of Messina", stage play, 1803) * ''[[Das Siegesfest]]'' (poem, 1803) * ''Wilhelm Tell'' "([[William Tell (play)|William Tell]]", stage play, 1803/04) * ''[[Die Huldigung der Künste]]'' (poem, 1804) * ''[[Demetrius (play)|Demetrius]]'' (stage play, incomplete, 1805)

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{use British English|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Sir William Jackson Hooker | image = William Jackson Hooker 1850s3.jpg | image_size = 240px | caption =Hooker in the 1850s | birth_date = 6 July 1785 | birth_place = [[Norwich]] | death_date = {{death-date and age|12 August 1865|6 July 1785}} | death_place = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = British | alma_mater = [[Norwich School (independent school)|Norwich School]] | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | known_for = Founding the Herbarium at Kew | author_abbrev_bot = Hook. | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | signature = William_Jackson_Hooker_Signature.svg | footnotes = | ethnicity = | field = [[Botany]] | work_institutions = [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]]
[[Royal Botanic Institution of Glasgow]] | prizes = | religion = }} '''Sir William Jackson Hooker''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|KH|FRS|FRSE|FLS|DCL|LLD}} (6 July 1785 – 12 August 1865) was an English systematic [[botany|botanist]] and organiser, and botanical illustrator. He held the post of [[Regius Professor]] of Botany at [[Glasgow University]], and was Director of the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]]. He enjoyed the friendship and support of Sir [[Joseph Banks]] for his exploring, collecting and organising work. His son, [[Joseph Dalton Hooker]], succeeded him to the Directorship of Kew Gardens.Allen, Mea 1967. ''The Hookers of Kew 1785–1911.'' Joseph, London. == Biography == Hooker was born in [[Norwich]]. His father, Joseph Hooker of [[Exeter]], a member of the same family as the celebrated theologian [[Richard Hooker (theologian)|Richard Hooker]], devoted much of his time to the study of German literature and the cultivation of curious [[plant]]s. He was educated at [[Norwich School (independent school)|Norwich School]] and afterwards took up as a recreation the study of [[natural history]], especially [[ornithology]] and [[entomology]].{{cite journal |title=The Self-Taught Botanists Who Saved the Kew Botanic Garden |author=Stearn, William T. |journal=Taxon |volume=14 |issue=9 |date=December 1965 |page=294 |publisher=International Association for Plant Taxonomy (IAPT) |jstor=1216740 |doi=10.2307/1216740}} He subsequently confined his attention to botany, on the recommendation of [[Sir James Edward Smith]], whom he had consulted respecting a rare [[moss]]. Hooker inherited enough money to be able to travel at his own expense. His first botanical expedition—at the suggestion of Sir [[Joseph Banks]]—was to [[Iceland]], in the summer of 1809. The specimens he collected, along with his notes and drawings, were destroyed by fire on the homeward voyage; an incident in which he nearly lost his life. His good memory, however, aided him to publish an account of the island, and of its inhabitants and flora; his ''Tour in Iceland'', 1809, was privately circulated in 1811{{cite journal|title=Review of ''Travels in the Island of Iceland, during the summer of the Year 1810'' by Sir George Steuart Mackenzie and ''Journal of a Tour in Iceland, in the Summer of 1809'' by William Jackson Hooker|journal=The Quarterly Review|volume=7|date=March 1812|pages=48–92|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.$b661434;view=1up;seq=60}} and reprinted in 1813.{{cite book|author=Hooker, William Jackson|title=Journal of a tour in Iceland, in the summer of 1809|location=London|publisher=Longman, Hurst, Orme, and Brown|edition=2nd|year=1813|url=https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001235821}} In 1810–1811 he made extensive preparations, and sacrifices which proved financially serious, with a view to accompany Sir [[Robert Brownrigg]] to [[Ceylon]], but political upheaval led to the project being abandoned. In 1814 he spent nine months in botanizing excursions in France, Switzerland and northern Italy, and in the following year he married Maria Dawson Turner, the eldest daughter of [[Dawson Turner]], banker, of [[Great Yarmouth]], and sister-in-law of [[Francis Palgrave]]. Settling at [[Halesworth]], [[Suffolk]], he devoted himself to the formation of his [[herbarium]], which became of worldwide renown among botanists. In 1816 the ''British Jungermanniae'', his first scientific work, was published. This was succeeded by a new edition of [[William Curtis]]'s ''[[Flora Londinensis]]'', for which he wrote the descriptions (1817–1828); by a description of the ''Plantae cryptogamicae'' of [[Alexander von Humboldt]] and [[Aimé Bonpland]]; by the ''[[Muscologia]]'', a very complete account of the [[moss]]es of [[United Kingdom|Britain]] and Ireland, prepared in conjunction with [[Thomas Taylor (botanist)|Thomas Taylor]] (1818);{{cite DNB |wstitle = Taylor, Thomas (d.1848) |last= Boulger |first=George Simonds |authorlink=George Simonds Boulger |volume = 55 }} and by his ''Musci exotici'' (2 vols., 1818–1820), devoted to new foreign mosses and other [[cryptogamic plants]]. In 1820 he accepted the regius professorship of botany in the [[University of Glasgow]] where he soon became popular as a lecturer; his style was both clear and ready. The following year he brought out the ''[[Flora Scotica]]'', in which the natural method of arrangement of British plants was given with the artificial. He worked with the [[Glasgow]] botanist and lithographer [[Thomas Hopkirk]] to establish the [[Royal Botanic Institution of Glasgow]] and to lay out and develop the [[Glasgow Botanic Gardens]]. In 1815, he was made a corresponding member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]], and, in 1833, his status was changed to that of foreign member. He was elected a Foreign Honorary Member of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1823.{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780–2010: Chapter H|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterH.pdf|publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|accessdate=9 September 2016}} Hooker succeeded in convincing the British government that botanists should be appointed to their expeditions. While his works were in progress his herbarium received large and valuable additions from all parts of the globe, and his position as a botanist was thus vastly improved. He was made a Knight of the [[Royal Guelphic Order]] and a [[Knight Bachelor]] in 1836, and in 1841 he was appointed director of the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]], on the resignation of [[William Townsend Aiton]].Kew had formerly been a royal garden; Hooker was the first Director under its new state ownership. Turrill W.B. 1959. ''The Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, past and present''. London. Under his direction the gardens expanded from {{convert|10|to|75|acre|ha|abbr=out}}, with an arboretum of {{convert|270|acre|km2}}, many new glass-houses were erected, and a museum of [[economic botany]] was established. He was engaged on the ''Synopsis filicum'' with [[John Gilbert Baker]] when he contracted a throat infection then epidemic at Kew. He died in 1865 and is buried at [[St. Anne's Church, Kew]]. He was succeeded at Kew Gardens by his son Sir [[Joseph Dalton Hooker]], a rare example of an outstanding man succeeded in his post by an equally outstanding son. ===Standard author abbreviation=== {{botanist|Hook.|Hooker, William Jackson}} ==Works== [[File:William Jackson Hooker 1860s2.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Hooker in 1863–64]] *''Exotic Flora, indicating such of the specimens as are deserving cultivation'' (3 vols., 1822–1827) *''Account of Sabine's Arctic Plants'' (1824) *''Catalogue of Plants in the Glasgow Botanic Garden'' (1825) *''Botany of Parry's Third Voyage'' (1826) *''[[Curtis's Botanical Magazine]]'' (38 vols., 1827–1865) *''Icones Filicum'', in concert with Dr R. K. Greville (meaning "Illustrations of Ferns"; 2 vols., 1829–1831) *''[[British Flora]]'', of which several editions appeared, undertaken with Dr G. A. W. Arnott, &c. {{Orphan|date=June 2014}}
[[File:Brooklyn Museum 22.1138 Figure of Mother and Child Phemba.jpg|thumbnail|Phemba from the collection of the Brooklyn Museum]] [[File:Brooklyn Museum 22.1136 Figure of Mother and Child Phemba.jpg|thumbnail|Phemba from the collection of the Brooklyn Museum]] [[File:Maternité Phemba-Kongo.jpg|thumb|right|A Phemba sculpture from a private collection in France]] '''Phemba''', also known as '''[[Yombe people|Yombe]] maternity figures''', refers to sculptural objects that depict the figures of a mother and child.<ref name="AfAmInstitute1980">{{cite book | title=Masterpieces of the People's Republic of the Congo: the African-American Institute, September 25, 1980-January 24, 1981 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kaPuAAAAMAAJ | accessdate=28 May 2013 | year=1980 | publisher=African-American Institute | page = 6}}</ref><ref name="Phyllis2009">{{cite book | author=Phyllis Martin | title=Catholic women of Congo-Brazzaville: mothers and sisters in troubled times | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4DWqkajkbmUC&pg=PA197 | accessdate=28 May 2013 | year=2009 | publisher=Indiana University Press | isbn=978-0-253-22055-4 | pages=197–}}</ref> Phemba are iconic examples of [[Kingdom of Kongo#Art_of_the_Kongo_Kingdom|Kongo art]] and according to Thompson (1981) "reflect the degree to which women are treasured in Kongo culture, not just for their fecundity, but as seers and guardians of the spirit".<ref name="Thompson 1981" />{{page needed|date=June 2018}} Kongo societies are [[matrilineal]].<ref name=Siegmann>{{cite book|last=Siegmann|first=William C.|title=African art a century at the Brooklyn Museum|year=2009|publisher=Brooklyn Museum|location=Brooklyn, NY|isbn=9780872731639}}</ref>
In special cases, communities honored women by commissioning stone icons depicting a mother and child to be placed on their tombs. This was also considered dangerous, as it represented an insertion of the source of life - the mother - into the world of the dead.<ref name="Thompson 1981">{{cite book|last=Thompson|first=Robert Farris|title=The four moments of the sun : Kongo art in two worlds|year=1981|publisher=National Gallery of Art, Washington|location=Washington, D.C.|isbn=089468003X|author2=Cornet, Joseph }}</ref>
The [[Kikongo]] word ''phemba'' translates to "the white",<ref>Herbert M. Cole, ''ICONS'' (1989), p. 89.</ref> in reference to the white earth ([[Kaolinite]]) that is a sign of fertility in the region. The name is interpreted by [[John M. Janzen]] (1979) as denoting "'the one who gives children in-potentia.' A phemba child is a magically conceived [[nkisi]] child, a fragile emissary of the spirit world."<ref name="African Religions">{{cite book|title=African religions: a symposium|year=1979|publisher=NOK Publishers|location=New York|edition=2nd printing, corr.|editor=Newell S. Booth,}}</ref>
Phemba statuary falls into two groups: mothers cradling or holding their babies, and mothers nursing.<ref name="Thompson 1981" /> The very different styles of phemba sculptures illustrate regional and even personal variations on the same theme. Oral tradition holds that the phemba cult was established by a famous midwife.
